The US Environmental Protection Agency will stop considering lives saved when setting rules on air pollution.

Credit: Vojtech Vosecky for sharing this graphic.

Instead, they'll monetise only the… | Matt Mahmood-Ogston
description:
The US Environmental Protection Agency will stop considering lives saved when setting rules on air pollution.

Credit: Vojtech Vosecky for sharing this graphic.

Instead, they'll monetise only the compliance cost to businesses.

Let that sink in for a second.

For decades, the agency showed that health benefits from cleaner air far outweighed compliance costs. Fewer premature deaths. Fewer kids in hospital with asthma. Fewer heart attacks.

Those calculations made it clear: protecting people was worth it.

Now, those lives won’t be monetised in EPA’s core economic calculation.

The pollutants in question aren't minor irritants. PM2.5 and ground-level ozone are among the deadliest air pollutants we know. They kill. They hospitalise. They shorten lives.

But apparently, quantifying that is too uncertain.

What's certain is this... when you remove the value of human life from your cost-benefit analysis, you make it exponentially easier to weaken protections. 

You shift the entire framework toward one question: what does this cost companies?
Not: how many people will this save?

This isn't just an American problem.

We're seeing this pattern globally. A quiet recalibration where corporate profit edges ahead of public health and protecting human lives. Where the cost of compliance becomes the only metric that matters.

It's a backward step dressed up as methodological refinement.

Every regulation that protects air quality is also protecting someone's parent, someone's child, someone's future.

When we stop counting those lives, we're not being more rigorous. We're just deciding they don't matter enough to measure.

And that's a trend we can't afford to normalise.

Because once you stop valuing life in your equations, it becomes a lot easier to sacrifice it in your decisions.

---

Many impact organisations make the same mistake without realising it. You report outputs because they're concrete: workshops delivered, people reached, hours of service. 

But funders don't invest in outputs. They invest in transformed lives. That single mother who avoided homelessness because of your housing support needs to be real to the person reading your grant application. 

Not as a case study. As a human being whose life trajectory changed because you existed. 

When institutions remove human lives from their measurements, your job becomes putting those lives back in. 

That's not just communications. 
That's accountability.

If you're working in social impact and need to turn your work into stories that funders and project sponsors actually care about, I send one practical storytelling framework every Thursday.

You get frameworks, templates, and AI prompts you can use immediately. No hot air. Under 10 minutes to read.

Join here: https://lnkd.in/ed_cxXbZ

title: How well can we predict chemical toxicity?
description: The total number of chemicals on the world market continues to increase, and traditionally, risk assessment of these chemicals have been made with data from exposed model organisms. This is both time consuming and costly, and instead models are being used to fill data gaps. But how good are these models, and can we trust the predictions? This seminar will give insight into how well established models can predict toxicity and also present a new model used in predicting chemical toxicity for a broad range of chemicals.

title: Long-term apple orchard cultivation drives selective accumulation and moderate ecological risk of heavy metals in loess Plateau, China - Scientific Reports
description: The long-term intensive cultivation in apple orchards has led to certain heavy metals accumulation yet the relative contributions of fertilizer inputs versus atmospheric deposition remain poorly resolved. Therefore, it is crucial to assess the effect of long-term cultivation on heavy metal pollution in soils of apple orchards, for safe and sustainable fruit production. Unlike the most studies that analyzed only surface soils, this study compares two soil depths with multiple cultivation-age classes and deep-profile background values, supported by positive matrix factorization (PMF) modeling, to distinguish fertilizer-derived and atmospheric sources. A total number of 128 soil samples were collected from two depths (0–20 and 20–40 cm) in apple orchards of varying ages up to 30 years. Overall, the soil pH was alkaline with high soil organic matter, total nitrogen, total phosphorus, total potassium and heavy metal contents. The concentrations of Hg, Cu, and Pb in orchard soils significantly increased with cultivation age at rates of 0.00165 mg kg−1, 0.244 mg kg−1, and 0.208 mg kg−1 per year (equivalent to 4.34%, 0.88%, and 1.11% per year relative to background levels), respectively, while Zn, As, and Cr showed no significant accumulation over time. The cumulative pollution load index of heavy metals was at moderate level in both depths (1.10 and 1.05 respectively). The single heavy metals pollution load index was variable Pb pollution load was high at 0–20 cm depth and Hg at 20–40 cm depth. The cumulative ecological risk index was at considerable level at both depths. However, the single ecological risk index of Hg was only at moderate level. Hg ecological risk is dominated by atmospheric deposition, while Cu, Pb, Zn, As, and Cr are fertilizer-driven. Ecological risk is based on total concentrations; bioavailability was not measured. The PMF model identified inorganic and organic fertilizers as the major contributing factors in Cu, Zn, As, Pb and Cr accumulation, whereas Hg accumulation was mainly due to atmospheric deposition. The study suggests regulating the use of fertilizers inputs and implementing control and remediation practices for sustainable fruit production in apple orchards.

title: Apple's Environmental Chief Lisa Jackson Retiring After 13 Years
description: Apple recently announced that its environmental chief Lisa Jackson would be retiring this month, and today she was removed from the company's leadership page. Since 2013, Jackson served as Apple's Vice President of Environment, Policy, and Social Initiatives, reporting to Apple CEO Tim Cook. In this role, she oversaw Apple's renewable energy and energy efficiency initiatives. Apple aims to become carbon neutral across its entire business, manufacturing supply chain, and product life cycle by 2030.

name: Costs & Impacts
title: U.S. Supreme Court Will Decide if Chemical Manufacturers Can Be Sued for Failure to Disclose Pesticide Hazards - Beyond Pesticides Daily News Blog
description: (Beyond Pesticides, January 17, 2026) The public‚Äôs right to sue chemical manufacturers that do not warn of product hazards will be up for review by the U.S. Supreme Court later this year, the justices decided Friday. Bayer/Monsanto is challenging billions of dollars in jury verdicts, which affirm longstanding jurisprudence that holds manufacturers responsible for disclosing hazards even when not required to do so by regulatory authorities. In the case being challenged, Durnell, John L. v. Monsanto, the injured party successfully argued that a chemical manufacturer has a duty to warn of potential hazards on their product label even though the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) does not require the warning. The failure-to-warn in the Durnell case resulted in a jury verdict of $1.2 billion and the total number of jury verdicts and settlements on similar cases may amount to over $10 billion in liability if the Supreme Court upholds the lower courts and hundreds of thousands of other plaintiffs with the same claim. The cases involve exposure to the weed killer glyphosate (RoundupTM, which is the most widely used herbicide in the U.S. and worldwide, has been classified as posing a possible risk of cancer by the International Agency for […]
